div.p: THE MOCK-DUELLIST, OR, The French Vallet. A COMEDY.
Acted at the THEATRE ROYAL, By his Majesties Servants.
LONDON: Printed by J. C. for William Crooke, at the Green Dragon without Temple-bar. 1675.

div.head: TO THE VERTUOUS ACCOMPLISHED Lady, MADAM S. C.
div.p: THe French Vallet, according to his natural Insolence, throws himself at your feet; not in his broken English, with a Begar Madam, mee voul ave it de so, but in that Dialect used by the most refin'd Wits,— Vous supplye tres humblement Le regarder d'un aspect favorable.

Which blessing he vows is a sufficient saveguard against those three Fatalities of Books; Envy, Spight, and Malice. I know, Madam, that to have shrowded under your generous protection all that the greatest Gallantry of the two most Polite Nations of the world could have wound up to the highest sublimity of Wit, had worn some face of Justice, which might have rendred the presumption excusable; it being so generally known, that none with more reason
than your self, could undertake the Censure of what is so much your own; I mean La parfaite cognoissance du beau Monde. But Champagne's Crime can plead no excuse; and being beyond the reach of ordinary Clemencie, can have no other hopes, than in that goodness which shines with so much Lustre throughout all your actions. Take pitty of him, Madam; and while your hand is in, pardon also the liberty which his Advocate takes, of subscribing himself,

closer.signed: Your most humble Servant, P. B.

div.head: THE PROLOGUE.
div.l: YE who will judge, and ye that can indeed,
(And Right, rather than long Prescription plead,)
To both we equally do bow this night,
Owning the Power of one and th'other's right.
Our Poet says, h'as brought you a new Play,
Or if no new dish— dress'd another way,
And better too, he thinks— Plot, Humour, Wit,
(The Devil's in it if it do not hit)
Leading you not through horrid rugged ways;
Knows better how to please, than to amaze.
Of Lines of Wonder you have had enow,
That pose your Intellect, and th' Authors too;
And to this Ages spight will live perplex't,
To dare the Vnderstanding of the next.
His easier Scene no big-swoln rumbling speaks,
That while you look on't, like a Bubble breaks,
Tumbling along with an amazing noise;
But his accoast is gentle Nature's voice.
In this conceit he brisks, begins to swell,
And swears he shall come off at least as well
As some applauded Freemen of the Trade,
Whom neither Art nor Nature Poets made.
'Twere brave if 't would go thus, and you should be
Perswaded to believe't as well as he.
But he'll go less; for all this little Huff,
At other intervals he's tame enough,
And wisely then considers what is due▪
From his bold weakness, to such Powers as you;
You whose Prerogative is understood
To give the stamp, and make the Mettle good,
With Priviledge as great and unconfin'd
As his, who Leather into Money coin'd.

body.head: THE Mock-Duellist, OR, The FRENCH VALLET.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: ONce more I tell thee, Boy, thou shalt have Gold:
Wilt thou not take my word? By these two Reliques.

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: Prethee hold fast; thou hast but little hold.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Why, there's the thing, that's it whets my revenge;
The little flesh I lost on either side,
Through the severity of old Sir Amorous
The Justice that lives in that Corner-house,
Has swollen my spleen to that excess of rage,
That nothing but the greatest of Revenge
I can invent, is able to allay it.

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: It was sharp dealing, I must needs confess.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Most certain. Hear, what I've already done
In order to this business.

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: Out with't, man.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I am of late possess'd with the affections
Of a young Lady at a Boarding-school,
Who, notwithstanding her severe restraint,
Has made a shift to give me her consent
To Marry me.

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: To Marry thee, say'st thou?
I'th' name of Fortune, for what dost thou pass?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: For nothing less than a Lords younger Brother,
What with my Tongue, my Person, and Gay Clothes:
My stories have so tickled her young heart,
She wishes hard this day be at an end,
That in the darkness o'th' succeeding night
I might (as I have promis'd) steal her hence.

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: But what's all this to Sir Amorous Frost?
Let's hear what thy revenge prompts thee to do.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Why thus: in this servile sort of disguise
Thou seest, I have oftentime met our Justice;
As often pre-possest him with the love
Of my new Miss unto his Worship's person;
Insomuch, that what with Letters and Bills,
Together with some other circumstances
Too long to tell, I have so fill'd his head
With fingle-fangles, that he is resolv'd
This night (through her desires, as he thinks)
To get her off, by a Ladder of ropes,
And then to marry her. Now comes the sport:
Get you in readiness, 'twixt two and three
This very night, half a dozen stout Lads
Fitly disguis'd to act the Watch-mens parts;
Your rendezvous shall be at the street-end.
Fail not in this, and leave me to the rest.
I had almost forgot to let thee know,
That French man whom I cunningly got off
The last Sessions but two▪

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: An excellent Rogue!

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I have dispos'd of to our Amorous Knight,
As a present from his Miss.

div.l: Look, look, yonder he comes; step you aside:
We'll both in here, and mark what he will do.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Come, come, turn out I say.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Jerny mee voul
Et den your Madmoisel turn de you out:
Begar mee go tell de her you no propre
To make de Gentleman; you no most have
De French Vallet, dat is geanty, galland,
No fit for de you dat: Jerny most have
De doll, de Diable, de simple English man
To serve de you, dat can no tesh de you
De Gallantry; no so mosh as de spake.
Fee, fee, begar, no me shame for de you
Jerny, mee voul go, no.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Should he in spite
Go tell my Mistris this, it might spoil all,
When I consider that she put him to me,
By the means of her confident, that man
Who interchangeably conveys our Letters,
The sole Correspondencie we ever had,
Through her severe restraint: I must submit.
Champagne, do but reflect on what y'have done.
Y'have stolen my Linnen, lost your Hat and Clothes,
Spent all that Money I'd giv'n you to lay out,
Which was five or six pounds.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Mee lay it ote, Jerny.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: On your own self, and give me no accompt.
Home you come naked, hundred Boys at your heels;
Then fit your self afresh from my best store,
All without Licence.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Begar, 'tis no de fasson
De Franshe serviteur de ask de permission;
Look de your Papier, and you voul see
It is de mee devoir to sheet de you.
Begar, you no understand de Civilité
Francoise; you call de sheet, dat is simplement
De gaillardise, de tour d'addresse, Jerny.
It is meskin, begar.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: I must be quiet,
And for the present wink at all his faults;
But time will come, I shall alter the Scene.
Well, well, Champagne, upon condition
That for the future you'll live orderly,
All shall be now forgot. I will allow you
A Crown a day, and you shall promise me
That you'll be honest, and cheat me no more.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Vell, tosh de la? do mee lose bee de bargain,
Mee vould oblige de you. Come, give l'argent.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Well, well, let's in, and I'll give it thee there.

div.stage: As Sir Am. is going in, Shift steps to him, and gives him a Letter.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Another Letter?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Lest the former should fail,
In speaking not clear enough her intentions.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: How does she do? Does she look briskly on't?
Thou seest I do: speak; Is she chearful, man?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: As her Impatiencie, Sir, will permit.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Take this for thy reward.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I thank your Worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: 'Tis a very small hand: where are my Spectacles?
Now let me see.

body.p: Since you have been so punctual to observe all my Injunctions, I can no more doubt of your real Affections; I shall think the time long till I am clasp'd within the loving Circle of your arms. This night if you will come to receive me as yours, 'twixt one and two, I shall impatiently expect your presence at the second window next the Garden, where you will finde

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Let me see that again?
Yours wholly, Kath. Noble? 'tis just so.
I must not doubt your secrecie in this?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I'll be as secret to you as your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: 'Tis very well; that Vertue is a Jewel
Which must be set in Gold. Here, take the rest.
Only an earnest of my future love.
Thou must assist me in this my designe,
In this Amorous Theft.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Sir, I am yours.
I'll not be wanting: be you but disguis'd,
And I'll secure you all.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Trust me for that
I can do it naturally, as it were.
What odd disguise dost thou think would do best?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: A woman's dress, nothing were better, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Th'art in the right: but how should I come by it
Without suspition?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Leave that, Sir, to my care.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: I prethee do, and be sure not to fail
Precisely at th'appointed time and place.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I'd as soon disappoint a Rich young wife,
As fail your Worship, Sir. This night at two
I shall be punctual, Sir— to plague your heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Champagne, come here.
How dost thou like me now?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: O! ver vell—
Begar you loke de no, Justement,
Comme de young Gallant: you have de odre day▪
De bougre de hair all vitt, et no you have
De Peruque frisee; you vant
No more, Jerny, que de feat, vensh et drink.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Fight, wench, and drink? I'm old-dog at that.
This Love is a strange thing: I'm young again.
Henceforth to Justice I must bid adieu;;
That becomes not my Youth. Judge thou Champagne
Whether this Wig and Sute would fit the Bench.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: No par ma foy, es bettre too sand tim
For de la Commedy▪

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: How do I walk?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: O ho! mee tosh you dat.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: And sing? fa-la-la-la-

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Mee tesh you dat.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: And fence? ha ha!

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Mee tesh you dat.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Oddsniggs▪ I had forgot
My French, Champagne.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Oh! mee no tesh▪ you dat.
Odnigg, odnigg, dat pitiful, Jerny,
Dat justement come de povre diable.
Alon donc? Qu'on prenne sa lecon
Par la Mort, par la Teste.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Par la Mort, par la Teste.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Bon, Jerny.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Bon Jerny.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Aye? no saye bon Jerny.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Aye? no say bon Jerny.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Diable soit de la beste.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Diable soit de la beste.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ah! Jerny, holl, holl: no say after me,
Je donne au diable Madamoiselle.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Je donne, &c.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Si je ne suis le plus humble serviteur.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Si je ne suis, &c.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: De tous les serviteurs de vos Valets.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: De tous les serviteurs, &c.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Very goot! alon, encore!

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Very goot, alon, encore.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Non! Madamoiselle je suis rany d'avoir donné
Jusques dans la Contre escarpe de vos bonnes graces.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Madamoiselle, &c.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Fort bien? no for de dance, Alerte Jerny.
Stand de you very strait, just come de mee.
So, very goot.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Now let me see whether I have observ'd
Exactly her Commands: this is her Note,
Written with her own hand. In the first place,
You are to be apparell'd i'th' French Mode,
To have this French Vallet, Companion rather,
Who is to teach you to Dance, Sing, and Fight,
To speak a Norman, or a Gascon French;
To Swear and Curse, in the same Dialect;
And cheat you of your Linnen, Clothes, and Cash,
Before your face; at which you must but laugh.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Oh! O! do you see no? pray observe dat.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: And swear by Jove, it is a witty Knave.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Un Crown de day? mee loose be de bargain.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Then I must have you court some Gaysome Lady,
To accustom your self 'gainst you have me.
Jerny, Champagne, je had forgot this last.
Hast vous incontinent to Monsieur Coggin,
Et know quand je can waite upon the Madmoisell.
Madmoisell Phill. Airy, pour kiss her bais les mains.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ha! ha! ha! mee go presentement.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Champagne, did'st thou not laugh at me, just now?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ma foy un little.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: There's for thy pains. Be gone.
At thy return thou't finde me in the Hall.

div.head: SCENE II. A Street.
div.stage: Per. Phill. Phan. and Siss at a distance.
Per. in a Riding habit; the Women in Morning-dresses, and Vizard-masks.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I Had intelligence a fortnight since
Of his coming to Town to wooe the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: The Widdow Lovewealth, say'st?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: The very same
Which put me on the business you shall hear.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Out with't; I long to hear't.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Thus in short.
You are to know my adversion towards Crosby
Being grown up unto a hatred of him,
By the sad narrative which Madam Phanny
Had made me of his base treachery towards her,
Caus'd on the other hand a suddain growth
To those well-wishings I had for Sir Coggin
Into affections—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Otherwise call'd Love.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: It shall be what you please. This made me seek
All handsome means to break off those concerns
Which my Knight had, with th'interest Lady Lovewealth.
I soon made with his Sister a firm league,
And did so order things, 'tis now a week
That I lie in their Lodgings, where I have had
More opportunity to work my ends.
Last night I did contrive so, that a Letter
Was delivered into Sir Coggins's hands
In presence of me, with this Message to't▪
That it was sent from an unknown Lady▪
In which was mention'd, that he should meet this day
In the Piazza at four a clock a person
That likely would inform him of some things
Of his nearest concerns. He read the Note,
And presently assur'd the Messenger
He should not fail the assignation.
I had just parted with him, when I met
Timothy Clay, with his Man and his Dog,
Inquiring earnestly of each he met
Concerning me, who was but just gone by▪
When I met you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well, but what said Sir Cogging?
Did he not know thee, think'st?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Not in the least.
I told him in a counterfeited voice,
The Lady Lovewealth did despise him so,
That a Rival was entertain'd by this
In his own room: if therefore he'd desist
His pursuit in that place, a worthy Lady
Would entertain his Love, who surely had
Such an esteem for's person, as would amount
To th' making him her Husband.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What said he?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I did not give him time, but added strait,
That if he'd meet me in that place again
'Twixt five and six, I should inform him further.
To which he answer'd, that he would not fail.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How durst thou venter thy self all-a-lone
Without company with thee? Where is Siss?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Those two persons you see there—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Who be they? Dost thou know them?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Yes, I do.
The one is Madam Phanny, th'other Siss.
Thus all-along they've kept me company,
At such a distance as you see they observe.
Here's Tim. Clay, Brother, we must not be known.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Let me alone for that: art sure 'tis he?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: My life on't, man. T'is best I should retire,
And leave him to your handling: if he bite,
Bring him in the back-way, there I'll confirm
Whatever you have said.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Say no more, wench.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Do you know our Neighbour?

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Where she lives?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Perhaps I might, did I but know her name.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Why her name is pritty Mistriss Phill. Airy.
What say you now?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: That I do know the person;
And if you please, I shall conduct you to her.
I am her servant, Sir,

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Say'st thou me so, friend?
A-gad-a-mercie fecks; give him a groate,
Clunch; come, dispatch, a shall have a gray groate.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Oye, oye, soft there, pray let him earn it first.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: But harke you now, what kinde of servant pray?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My Profession, Sir—

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Oye, oye, let's hear, what's that?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Is to instruct both Gentlemen and Ladies
I'th' art of Compliments; besides, I shew
To such strangers as you, the Town and Court,
The Gallantry thereof, and the Intrigue—

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Intrigue? what place is that?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: By that I mean
Th'ingenious conversation 'twixt the Wits
Of either Sex, both in the Court and City.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: You say that you teach Compliments?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I do so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Why then I'll tell you friend, 'twixt you and I,
I'm come to town to court a certain Lady,
Who is already courted to my hands;
But that for fashion-sake (a murrain on't!)
I must bestow some few upon her Chaps.
Therefore, if you can help me to a brase
O'th' newest of them at reasonable Rate,
I'll be your Chapman: I have money enough;
Have I not, Clunch?

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Why, who dares question that?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I do not in the least.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: You were not best.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: But so few Complements, I am afraid
Will scarce serve turn.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Then keep them to your self,
For I could never yet learn how to write,
Scarce how to read; and do you think that I
Will burden my membry with Complements?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What if I teach you the new Mode of Courtship,
In which you'll need but one single Complement,
And all the rest is voluntary Wit?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I marry, now you say something indeed;
But what d'you mean by voluntary Wit?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis high Hyperboles, Anglicè Nonsense.
No matter, Sir, how wide 'tis from the matter,
So you but keep your Countenance, go on,
And scarce take time to breathe.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Those what you call—
Hyper-bullies, and Anglicè Nonsense,
I shall ne're learn without book, I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well, Sir, suppose I have a way for that?
What can you then object?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I am not, Sir,
For your objects, I'm for one Complement:
And if so, why then so. Fecks you and I
Will be better acquainted.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well, in short,
Because we are strangers to one another,
For further satisfaction, if you please
To let me wait on you to th' Lady Airy,
She will inform you of my Capacity
In my Profession.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Gad-a-mercie fecks;
A dad a speaks, Clunch, like an honest man:
Come, we'll along.

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: I Hope your Ladyship will none of him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Of whom talk'st thou?

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: Mr. Timothy Clay.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Thou silly thing! is he not wonderous Rich?

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: Yes, Madam, and that's all.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis all indeed:
For in that word is comprehended all
That I aspire at. Suppose he be
The ill-bred Chip of a rough-hewn block;
Impertinent, absurd, given to drink,
And to all sottishness; what's that to me?
I'll endeavour somewhat to polish him:
If I cannot succeed, he take that course,
And I will even take this—

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: Which, Madam, pray?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I'll give my self all the freedom I can
In modesty injoy; take th'advantages
Of all his beastly extravagancies.
I'll insinuate my self i th' management
Of the Estate; lull him asleep with ease;
Yield a full scope to all his appetites,
While I will work my ends, hoord up his Gold,
And spend on't at my list, on this, or that;
Eat, drink, wear what I please; as often change:
Go out, come in again, early or late,
Without controle; have servants for my turn:
All this, and all things else, as I think fit.
What more can I desire? would he were come:
I long to see the man.

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: Sir Coggin, Madam,
Th'obliging Knight, what must become of him?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Faith, Prew, e'en as he pleases; here 't
I'm for the Richest still.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: The Taylor, Madam
Has brought some Patterns for your Ladyship.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Per. Phill. Clay, Clunch and Tray.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: SIr, in a word, he is the only man
On all accompts of Gallantry, you could
Have pitch'd upon.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Avads I think a be?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: And for your sake, I'll dismiss him my service;
He shall be wholly yours.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Neighbour, good thanks.
You hear, Sir? henceforth y'are to be mine;
Our Neighbour says the word.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sir, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Why very well. Now, because I'm in haste,
I'd have you dogmentise me instantly.
Was not that a hard word?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Most excellent!

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Nay, sometimes I hit on um, do you see?
Come, give me some distructions.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Very well.
Now, Sir, observe, since I'm fully inform'd
You do not care for troubling of your self
With Compliments, I'll teach you the new Mode
A la Soldate.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Hy-day! what's that, I pray?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: That is to say, Soldierlike Courtship, Sir;
A kinde of rough-hewn way newly come up,
Which takes wonderous well in Court and City:
'Tis generally us'd.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I long to know't.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why thus in short: suppose that Lady there
Were your Maitress

div.stage: Per. comes up to Phill. in an affected way. Clay imitates redicul.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: That's Latin for my Lady?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: No, Sir, 'tis French: thus I make my approach.
'Tis very well.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Nay fecks let me alone
To speak all the dumb Courtship, do you see?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thus having kiss'd her hand, you must begin
Your Compliment.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Can't I do't without speaking?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Not without speaking, Sir: but do you mark,
That you may have no use of memory,
I'll write you down a Compliment.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Nay, nay,
That will not do: for to tell you the truth,
I could never yet read a written hand,
Except it were in print.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: It shall be so.
This done, and handsomely convey'd within your hat,
Which holding thus you shall read to you Lady,
She knowing not but you deliver it

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: That's French again; oye oye.
Efecks it will be brave.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Your Compliment
Delivered as is said, you must begin
Either to whistle, sing, hop up and down—

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Or else play with my dog. But tell me though,
Suppose my Lady speaks some Complements
To me again, what then?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why, if she do,
She will not greatly minde what you will say,
Neither must you minde her.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: 'Tis very true.
For why should I minde her, and she not me?
Let me alone for that. That is, you say—
A la— what do you call it?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A la Soldat.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I'll defie any single man in town
To do't better than I. Me thinks I'm at it.
Hie Tray! alas poor rogue!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: That's very well.
It is done to the life. After a while,
If you do find the Lady to be silent—

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: So let her be! so I would have her fecks.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You must begin—

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: No Complements, I hope?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Nay, then it will do well enough.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Only make use of some familiar talk:
As for example, What is most in fashion,
What News abroad, or else of some new Play.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Or of my dog Tray; or else, do you see,
Tell her how many Beasts, Sheep, Hogs; and Geese
My Father left me, besides, Money and Lands
In ready Cash.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: There's nothing better, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: But yet, suppose she has an itching minde
To Complement?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Then you must let her know
That being of opinion that Complements
Are of too soft a nature for a man
(Especially of mettal) for to use,
Y'have hired me to supply in that part.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Effecks it will be rare.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Then will I court—

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: The Lady, as for me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis very right.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Oddsniggs, I had forgot where w'are to go.

div.l: Where shall I meet you 'bout an hour hence?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sir, where you please.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Let it be in yond place—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: The Piazza, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Oye there an hour hence.
Neighbour Airy go to: y'have won my heart,
With leaving me your man.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Your servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Nay, nay, no Complements; and so farewel.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Brother, what think you on't?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Nothing but good.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: In my opinion, if I ben't mistaken,
Here is a fortune flung into your arms:
You can't avoid it man, it must be so;
You are the man design'd to have the Lady
When all is done.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I hope no less, e'faith,
As I shall carry it on: for I intend,
As you may well perceive by this beginning,
That under the pretence of good instructions,
I'll make this credulous shallow-pated fool
Appear to be such an impertinent Sot,
As will oblige the widdow without doubt
To see her folly in't if she once moves.
Then will I take fair opportunity
By the fore-top, and speak to her for my self.
That, Girl, must be the way.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: A good one too.
Where's our brother Dick? would he were here:
Have you not heard of him?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: By the last Post.
This is the day he is to be in town.
The fatal pass, which so infortunately
He was compell'd to make in's own defence
Upon his enemy, is no more thought on:
For underhand he has of late compos'd,
And (though with great expence) is gotten clear.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I fear of's money as well as his troubles.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: It can't be helpt.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: He deserves better things.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: His Ingenuity will never let him want.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I hope 'twill not.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Madam, Mr. Crosby
Demands admittance to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Why let him come; I shall soon dispatch him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Mean time I'll go about the Compliment
Of such a nature—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Into my Closet there.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Your humble Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Madam, I come to ease my poor sick heart.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: If you are serious, you'll be best alone.
I have, Sir, other business now in hand.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Let me beg you'll be pleas'd but to consider,
You can have none that may with greater Justice
Be taken to your thoughts, than such a passion
As I have always manifested to you,
By the saddest protests—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Those you call such
I must suppose are of your making so,
Perhaps it is your custom: I not the first
To whom y'have made those sad protests you call.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Let me but only vent—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: At leisure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: There's something more than ordinary in the wind.
Should she have had intelligence of late
Of my former Amours with Madam Phanny?
But how should she come by't? I need not fear't.
I must confess she ever did receive
All my addresses with reluctancie;
Would often twit me with her friends consent
Which I had got: but now of later daies
Sh'as not so much as common complaisance.
Well, I'm resolv'd once more to see this Miss,
And pump out, if I can, the cause of this.

div.head: ACT. II. SCENE I. Sir Coggin's house.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: DEre is de hoose, mee most knoke de dor:

div.l: Begar is be un very pritty de ting.
Mee voul make de her un grand Compliment.
Madamoiselle, je suis vostre esclave d'un grand coeur.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Bless us! what have we here?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Vat have you de heer? Jerny, you have de Geante,
Jolly, polly, accomply, galland Gentilhome, Monsieur
De Brisefer; une persone dat vill tesh de you de
Playe de Trumpet marine, de Flageolet, de
Feedle, de Tambour, de Basque, de Signe, come ca
Fa-la-la-la, de Compliments, de Dance, come ca ha—
De Fence, come sa, a, ha!— A Jerny mee voul feet,
A kill all de Diables for de love de you.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Sure this same thing has skipt out of its wits
Into this Morris-dress before the season?
Hear you, pray, is not your name Champagne,
Sir Amorous Frost his servant?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ha, a, a, Champagne?
Me Modre bring de mee in de Champagne, et—

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Upon her back?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: No, begar, no ope de her belee—
Aye, so mee come in de varl in Champagne.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: You were born there?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Very just, par ma foy, mee born, mee born der.
But mee name bee Monsieur de Brisefer admirateur
De vos perfections.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Goodnow, no more conjuring.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: For de love de you mee voul brake de neck presentement
Si'l vous plaist.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Good Sir, I thank you for your hanging love.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: A ha! vostre tres humble Valet.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Well, but Champagne?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Aye!—

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Or Monsieur Brisefer, what is your Arrand?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Harrang, begar, Jerny, mee have no de Harrang, look
Der els;
sp.stage: (Shews his pockets, opens his breast and breeches.
sp.l: Mee come to baise les mains de Madmoiselle
Diana, pour de service de mee Maistre.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: What stuff is this? you baise les mains, Sot?
You kiss her—

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Tout beau, tout beau, ma Genty de moiselle, ventre,
Teste, Gozoon, if de Rogue de Englishman speak de
Mee de Harrang, me kill de him come ca, ha!
Ho! com come Madamoiselle, sur mon honneur
Mee voul no kill de you, harrang,
Jerny—

div.stage: Makes a Pass at Lysse; she runs, shreeks, he holds her back.
div.l: You say mee sell de Harrang?

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Arrand, yes, Sir, I'm going of one,
And should be glad you would inform me in't:
Pray where lives one whose name's Sir Hopewell Coggin?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Coquin? par la sang, par la mort, par la teste, Gozoon,
Harrang? Coquin? if no respect de Madmoiselle
Mee voul— hum? Jerny— behange—

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: This is excellent sport!

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Jerny, your self: sure this fellow is mad.
What do you say to me, pritty one? ha?
Can you inform me?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Jerny, he live in de house.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Pray leave off your Jerny: it may be so.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Sot? Madamoiselle pray you hold de mee fast,
Autrement mee kill de him presentement.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: In what place is this house?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: In London, Jerny.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Jerny in your teeth:
I'm a meer stanger, and—

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Et mee be un persone voul make de you mad.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: where might I see him?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ver you look o-top de him, Jerny?

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Again? y'are pleasant, Sir?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Begar me var mor plaisant if you go to de divle
Si Josois, Jerny—

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Flesh and bloud can't hold out;
H'as gin me the Jerny a dozen times.
Pray change me this?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Peste?— is it de jest ou bien de tout de bon?

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: E'en as you please; what do you think on't, pray?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: De jest, de jest, your humble serviteur.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Much good may do you, Sir: I'll go with you.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: La peste? come il touche?—
Ha teste non? ou est I'honneur? Champagne, ou est I'honneur?
Begar, mee voul have de revange; first mee vill kill
De Rogue, and den mee cogel im sounlgle. Hah! Rogue,
Tosh mee de face? Premierement, call de mee de harrang,
Teste non? en second lieu, call de mee de Coquin? Par
La mort? Item, call de mee Sot? ha! ventre blew?
Conclusion, zap, give en grand box de Ear? ha! Jerny?
Es Justment come ca? dat is de ting. Mon honneur?
Verbee you? allon viste speak de me.
Mee say most have de respect for de Estranger—
Autrement mee kill de him, van, too, tree tim. O! forbon,
Very goot, you see no, mee honneur ave de respect et
De consideration for de Estranger?— but mee honneur
Be un ting, et me un odre; me say nothing, but
Jerny—

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: leading Phill. Noble, Diana, Lysse, Siss.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: ON my word, Madam, there was no such thing.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: But what then may it be?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Love, Madam, may,
And with such fierceness drive on these designes
As will compass his ends—

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Not always, Sir—
Brother, say what you please, but let me think:
Go out so suddenly, come home in dumps,
Have not a word to say; nay scarce afford
Common respect to your most worthy guests,
Is somewhat strange.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: He knows I am not his,
But your poor tenant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: I must confess,
That an odd business coming unexpected,
Has somewhat discompos'd me for the present,
For which I humbly beg your pardon, Madam.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: You have it;
But under favour, Sir, may we not know
What sort of business 'twas you had in hand?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: I hope it was no quarrel?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Was it not some gay Lady's assignation?
That Note that was deliver'd you last night,
In my minde, spoke so much.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: To tell the truth,
It was that very thing: I had intelligence
Of an amour.

div.stage: Enter Boy: whispers Diana, and Phill.

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: What now, Sirrha?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Moving already, Ladies?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: To th'next room.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Once more, Sir, you are welcome to this house,
And wish you quick success in your addresses
Unto my Sister, who already's inform'd
Of your own worth; and do believe that she
Will not be o're-severe in the reception
Of your love beyond what's to be allowed
To th' modesty of her Sex.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Your Generosity
Is so surprising, that I'm to seek for words
To return you those thanks that might proportion
With your civilities.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Y'are still beforehand: my Sisters Portion, Sir,
Is yet entire, though I've had the misfortune
To loose my share of what we had inherited
From our Parents.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Had I any thoughts
That in the least should reflect upon interest,
'Twould render me unworthy the possessing
So rich a Jewel as that Lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Y'are too obliging, Sir,— who have we here?

div.stage: Sir Amorous leading Phill. and Diana singing.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Falla-la-la; Jerny Madmoisell vostre tres humble serviteur.
Neece! how is't, Girl? Monsieur je suis a vous.
Nephew! how dost thou like this Peruque? ha!
This Trimming, Cravat, these Gloves, Sword and Belt?
The whole Apparel? hum? falla-la-la.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: What the devil's the matter?
What your judicious Gravity approves,
I am not to contest—

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Sure he is mad?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: I've always told you, Nephew, that delays
Were ever of a dangerous consequence;
And now y'are like to know it by experience.
You know how oft I've advis'd you to marry,
That I might see some likelyhood of Heirs
To be successors to that fair Estate
I have acquired, by my assidual pains.
You have had time enough, yet nothing done:—
'Tis those neglects of yours, have put me on
This great necessity of marrying
In these more riper years.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: The wench guest well—
I suppose, Sir, this is to try me with?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Mistake not; I'm in earnest, and in haste.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Why, Sir, the Gentleman is young enough;
And his lost time may easily be repair'd
(I'm of opinion) if it pleases him.
'Tis in his choice yet, to out-strip you there.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Where, prithy? where?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I mean in Marriage, Sir,
My Knight takes me not yet; I dare no more—

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: I thought you knew the person, I protest.
I shall scarce marry these three or four daies,
And you may get a dozen wives by then;
But he must make good haste, or come too short.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: You say three or four daies?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Yes, thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Well, Sir, will you but yield that if I marry—

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: The widdow Lovewealth? I'll put a spoke there.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: A Lady young and brisk, 'twixt this and when
You have appointed for your marriage-day,
You will—

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: I'll tell thee, nephew, what I'll do:
He that is first married of us two,
Shall bar the other from procuring Heirs
To my Estate.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: A match, a match, e'faith.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: And if Sir Cogging, Sir, does get the day,
You'll declare him your Heir immediately?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: What say you, Sir, to that?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: A match, a match;
I'll not deny you sweet: you must run post?

sp.speaker: Nobl.
sp.l: 'Tis very well.

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: We'll all be witness to't.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: And to my wedding also morrow-morn.
To which y'are all invited.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: How? so soon, Sir?
Y'allow'd a longer time.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Three or four daies?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Nay, Sir, 'tis so; now make what haste you can;
Whip, whip, and spur, y'had need, or lie behinde.
I'll stick to th' Contract; so Gentles, adieu.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: What a mad Scene is this?

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: 'Tis unexpected—

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.l: And sudden too, I think.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: These the first news;
But now, what's to be done?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: E'en cross his Match.

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: But how is't to be done?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: W'are left i'th' dark:
Did we but know where he makes his address,
There would be some hopes yet.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Sir, as for that,
I think I have a way which may succeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Prithy what is't?

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: You know, he has of late
Entertain'd a French servant.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: What of that?

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: The fool, who pretends kindnesses to me,
Is doubtless privy to his Masters love;
And if so, Sir, I make no question then,
But to get knowledge of this secrecie.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: No better way.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Lysse, if thou do'st this,
Thou wilt deserve our further care of thee.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Let me alone to worm out this French fellow;
Sir, fear it not.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Come, chear up, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, you may do so,
Who have assurances of your amours
By a Contract—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: A Contract say you, Sir?
(Curse be the cause of this suspicion in him.)
'Tis with my Parents then, never with me.
And likely enough that bargain's yet to make
Between the Gentleman you mean, and me.

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: Brother, let me advise you strait to go
To th' Lady Lovewealth; learn if 'twere the hopes
Of your Uncles Estate made her accept
The tender of your services, or whether it be
A real affection does cause her to have
An esteem for your person. If the last,
Inform her how y'are driven—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Not amiss.
So now it works as I would have it, just.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Sir, if you please to honour me so far
As to lend me your company t'her house—

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.l: It must be then with these two Ladies leave.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: I'll but call by the way at the Rose-tavern.

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.l: In the mean time, according to my promise,
I'll speak two words at the School in next street.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Very well, Sir, we'll meet at the Piazza
An hour hence.

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.l: Till then, your servant, Sir.

div.head: SCENE III. The School-house.
div.stage: Kitty Noble, at a window; Shift in the street, in a fine Garb.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: NOw I'm a Prince again, in shew at least.
Hem! hem!

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: Hist, hist.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: 'Tis I; is the coast clear?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: I'll look about— I see none we may fear.
Why did you stay so long?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: How does my Love?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: As well as hopes can make me,
And yet my thinks this day is cruel long.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: It draws towards its end.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: Does the time hold?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: 'Twixt two and three: be sure the ●●ght be out;
Our work requires none.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: How shall we do
To get off in the dark? the Moon by twelve
Will yield us no more light.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: So I would hav't.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: It will be very dark: how shall I know
When you are come, or whether it be you?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Here, here; secure these half a dozen Keys:
When I am got up to the Ladder-top,
I'll in the Room, and seek you in the dark,
Where when you finde y'are taken by the hand,
Conclude 'tis I. By the help of these Keys
I'll open every door to th' Garden-side,
And that way we'll get off. Speak not a word,
Nor whisper then.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: And where must we go then?
Not far, I hope.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Only to the Church-porch,
Where a Parson shall wait to tye the Knot,
And then—

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: Away, away, the Beldam comes.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Farewel till night.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: Farewel.

sp.speaker: Crost.
sp.l: FOr these same reasons, Sir, a stricter Eye
I've kept upon her actions than before;
And till some two months since, or thereabouts,
I could not finde she had any commerce
Beyond these walls; which made me grant to her
A little more liberty than before.
But it could not last long: for one bright night,
About the hour of two, I heard a noise
On the back-side; I stole gently down stairs,
And there, you'll scarce believe't—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Yes, I'll believe that she has not her like.

sp.speaker: Crost.
sp.l: I found the Gentlewoman
Letting down of a bucket full of stones
Into a Well.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: How's that, pray? full of stones?

sp.speaker: Crost.
sp.l: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Crost.
sp.l: I stood still close behinde,
And she was so attentive at her work,
That she perceiv'd me not: now mark, I pray!
Anon at th'other end of the Well-rope,
Up comes, what do you think, Sir? pray you guess.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: The Devil sure.

sp.speaker: Crost.
sp.l: No, Sir, but one of's friends,
Drest in a humane shape; a fine young man,
Who, as I thought, none but the Devil himself
Could have brought there. The Gallant spying me
Standing behinde, twitches the rope she held,
And gently poises himself down again.
At this she turns, and so espies me out.
You must needs think she was much discompos'd
At the sight of me?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: Crost.
sp.l: Wounderfully! she in a laughing tone
Cries out, E'faith, you came i'th' nick of time,
Or else by this, I'd gin you the go-by.
With that, in a great laughter up she runs,
Where having lock'd her self, she 'gan to sing,
Oh! Love is a dilicate thing. I'th' morning
I visited the Well, and in it found
Towards the middle, a window that did answer
Into a neighbouring Vault. I had a pump
Set in the place, to prevent for the future
Such like attempts. Seeing no remedy
But close confinement of her in a Room
Under good locks and keys, I've mew'd her up,
Where she does still remain.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Cannot be helpt.
I pray let her not know of my return
Till I see you again. Till then, farewel.
I see 'tis easier the Ocean to span,
Than keep by force a young maid from a man.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.
div.stage: Crosby, as he is going in, meets Siss.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: NOw for to know my doom. Your Lady, Siss?

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: She's gone to take the Air.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Come, let me in.
I shall grow angry else.

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: Here comes some Rescue?

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Your obedient Servant, your Woman, Madam,
Deni'd you to me.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: She did nothing, Sir,
But what she had in charge.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis like
(My fate's the harder) that I am ariv'd
Upon some newer interest.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Your own
Was not so considerable, Sir, before,
Nor had it so much name you need to fear
That any should succeed it.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: If there be any one dares own a favour
That's to my prejudice, let him look, Madam,
You hide him in your bosome, if he would not
Have this sword through him.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Sir, you must prescribe
No Laws to me: that person I shall chuse
To throw my favours on, shall know to answer
Whatever heats you bring.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Why be it so.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: This care is over.

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: A fair riddance, doubtless.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: This is not all, I have another plot,
To bring about my ends 'twixt Madam Phanny,
And this unworthy man, that I must do,
Or I've done nothing yet.

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: Seriously, Madam,
I pitty that poor Lady at my heart,
She is so melancholy—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Where is she now?

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: At her old trade of weeping.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I'll chear her up
E're long; if things do hit.

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: Pray Heavens they may.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Let's in, and there consult with her about it,
Lest we be troubled with this impertinent.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: CHampagne? dis de honneur es un Jewel
De grand estimation: it is de so pretious de ting
Dat mos no bee loss; no, mos no be loss:
Den mon revenge: Oh! very goot, very sweet,
Par ma foy de hony is no so sweet
As de revange to de Frensh Vallet.
Derefor, par consequent you de Estranger
Dat give de mee de pas ope de face,
You moss prepare for de dy, no remedee,
But Monsieur Champagne, mee mande pardon,
Mee ask quarter, de grace mee no give:
Comment give box de Ear to mee person?
Ah! Jerny, ventre teste, come nee I doon,
Dat mee cope de teste, et present de it
To mee Maistresse Madamoiselle Lysse.
Alon; mee no longre stay: point de quartier.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: How now? who's that you'll kill?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ha! Monsieur mon amy, begar mee be
Your very de humble Serviteur— mee very glad
De see de you ver vell, mee voul present de you
Vit de pint de vin.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: But my thinks you were grumbling
In an other dialect?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Es nothing, par ma foy:
Mee only repete de vers de la Comedy.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Perhaps y'are angry?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: No, no, sur mon honneur.
Mee know you de jest, mee no angry, Mafoy:
You strick de mee again if you de plaise,
Mee never tink de arm vit de amis.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Then fare you well, I've nothing more to say.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Humble Valet; Jerny, mort teste non:
Mee no do vell, mee shoull have kill de him:
A ventre blew, mee voul call de him back.
sp.stage: Runs towards the door, then comes back.
sp.l: Dis fool pittee always take de mee
A contre temps: begar for de futur
Mee voul be cruel, batre, kill, cojel,
Massecre all to mee revange. Jerny,
Mee voul presentement go send de him
Un shalange, but first mee vill visit
Mee Maistresse Madmoiselle Lysse, Jerny,
To give de mee de la valleur— Ah! pox de him.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: I had forgot that while y'are here, you should
Present my humble service to that Lass
I met with you i'th morning, and let her know
I'll visit here e're long: do not you fail.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Jerny?

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: What's that you say?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ouy, ouy, dat is de say, iss, iss, presentement,
Oll, oll, a little, mee do you de service.
Dere no is vell.

div.stage: Exit Slye: Champ. looks after him a good while, then draws.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Oh! thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Hum, um, um, Jerny; 'tis vell you go,
You make de scape, but mee cash you agin
Un odre tim— mee voul extermin de you.
Oh! Madmoisell, for de grand love de you,
Mee almost kill van, to, tree Rogue, just no.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: For love of me?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Is par la mort. Jerny.
Mee love de you tresfurieusement.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: I, but how shall I know if this be true?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Sur mon honneur; mee engage mee honneur.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Were I but sure—

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: O! mee voul tell de you?
Commande no, de mee de un ting,
Et mee voul do de ting: you ondrestand?

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: That you'll do any thing I shall command?
Well, I'll trie you for once.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Come donc, allon.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: With whom is't that your Master is to marry?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Dat be begar de very grand secret;
Mee Mastre vill no have de know, Jerny.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: I thought as much: I see your love in this:
You love? you hang.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Madmoiselle Lysse, pray come to mee, mee voul tell de you
De all; but you most be de very secret den?
Autrement— hum, um, um—

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Fear it not, man:
I'll be in this as secret as thy self.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: De Mrs. de mee Mr. is un little Gentilhoman
In de Schoole, vish mee Mr. take de away in de neet.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Who? Sir Amorous?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: No, no, Jerny, un odre:
Mee tell de you de all; mee have too Mr;
Premierement, de un dat is un Rogue;
Secondement, that Rogue pote de mee
To de odre dat is un fool—

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Sir Amorous you mean?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Just so, Jerny: no, mee Mr. de Rogue,
Voul all de sheet, d'odre Mr. de fool,
Et take de vensh for him: begar, just so.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Is it this night?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Is, is, but moss silance.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Here's cheat on cheat: hark, hark! somebody comes.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Mee voul come de see you after un hour.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Do so, be sure you come: you'll finde me here.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Adieu, begar, de nexe tim mee see de you
Mee vill see if you be de goot flesh; Jerny mee
Can no stay de longre for un homan.

div.head: SCENE III. Lovewealth's house.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: PRew? go to my Closet, and fetch me the Letter
I now receiv'd from Sir Amorous Frost.
It is both short and sweet. While I took care
How to dismiss Sir Coggin of his sute,
There is provision made; I need no more,
When he's come in, but to shew him this Note:
Sure that will do't. How now?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir Coggin, Madam,
Is new set down at door, desires admittance
To your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why, bring him in— that's well:
I am prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, I have made bold—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You have so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Yet I hope the offence
Is not so great but that I may finde pardon?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis of that nature, Sir, as must not hope
To finde excuse, much less a pardon for it.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Madam, I hope, 'tis not on my accompt
My friend is thus neglected by your Ladyship?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No such thing, Sir; if y'are rich you are welcome:
But for that Gentleman, (your friend you call)
That knows himself to be wretchedly poor,
Beyond all hopes, and yet pretend to me,
Is such a thing as I must not forgive.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: 'Tis likely, Madam, that some Rival here
Is hapyer than I?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: He is so, if more Rich:
That is the only thing, Sir, that sways me.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, in the opinion of the general,
There are other things to be consider'd
In the choice of a Husband.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: The Vulgar, say you?
That commonly runs false; and I'll be singular,
Sir, thus in short: were you in full possession
Of as fair an Estate as is your Rival,
Your person, Sir, might pass muster with me;
I like that well enough.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Come, come away;
For shame, Sir, do not spend one single thought
Upon so interest a thing as this,
Who is a scandal to her gentler Sex.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Indeed! are you of that Religion too?
Here, Sir, read this, and then tell me your minde?

body.p: I hope you will attribute these few lines of advice to my diligent care of your Welfare, since they tend to no other end, than the giving you notice that I am in minde to have Heirs of my own getting, and leave my Nephew to his Ingenuity. I make no question but you know my meaning: So conclude,

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Your Uncle has been too quick for you here.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, since it is so, yet give me leave
To congratulate my Rival e're I go.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, To speak the truth, I had intelligence
He would be here this day; but yet, not come.
I'th' evening, Sir, if you please to be here,
You'll witness our Contract.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: And Marriage too?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: If he has a minde to't.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, I'll come.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Your Friend too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Your thrifty Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: So much for that: now shall I think it long
Till my new Lover comes. I wonder what
His Compliment will be?

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: By relation, Madam,
He cannot say, as a body should say,
As one should say, boh! to a Goose.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Go to:
How goes the day?

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: Madam, on its decline.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And not come yet?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A strange Gentleman, in as strange a dress,
Madam, demands access unto your Ladyship,
Both for himself, his mouth, his man, and dog.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What's this thou say'st?
Admit him here.
Sure this is he, by the Message he sent.
I dread his coming in, who just before
Wish'd he were here: I must receive him now.
It is too late to think.

div.stage: Clay takes his Compliment from Per. pins it to his Hat, comes up to the Lady, makes a Leg, then falls back again, hems, spits, and Coughs; blows his Nose on the ground, then wipes it on his sleeve.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Come here, poor Rogue.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Now minde your business, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.p:
Madam, super Excellent, and the sole supreme Mistris of my sober Passions, (hem, pat the Dog) paron— hum— pardon, that my peregrine self intreats the Mixifick effects of the sweet Influentials of your, of your,— your— Loxogonos— phe— ri-cal Intuition. You sublime Lady alone, are able to nurce up this— (hem again.) (a pox of these hard words) ex— exta— extatickal embryo of your more than thrice supedaneous Admirer. (hem again.
Give me leave super Mundaine Lady, to supplicate at the (now-now again) sub-t-e-r-ter-sel of your feet; and pardon him who subscribes himself your slave, as far beneath your pitty, as a Myrmidonial Insect to highest of Stairs; no, Stars I mean.

div.stage: (Vnpins the Paper, gives it to Per.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.p: So much for the Compliment Clunch, want it well done? efecks, 't has made me sweat. This thing call'd wooing, is a most pest'lant thing. Lady, if you'd have more, I've brought my mouth with me, d'you see, to speak for me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, in few words, y'are welcome to my house.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: It is not quite so big as our new Barn:
What thinks thou, Clunch?

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Yea, thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: There's nothing can be more ridiculous:
'Tis the meer abstract of impertinencie;
Worse cannot be.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I am glad to hear that.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What have I done?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: How do you like my Dog?
sp.stage: (Holds up his Dog to the Lady.
sp.l: Do you see, Madam, en't it a fine thing?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Oh! very fine indeed, and nothing finer.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Come hither, Tray? what do you think's his name?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why Tray I think.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Efecks y'are in the right;
sp.stage: Clay sets him down, sets Tray in another chair, leaves the Lady standing.
sp.l: That you should guess, d'you see, so well at first!
Did she not, Clunch?

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Yea, yea, what was't you said?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Effecks, I'm glad to see you well: sit down.
Ho! fetch a stool for my Lady to sit.
sp.stage: Clay plays with the Dog, whistles so loud, be drowns all that they say.
sp.l: Mouth, do you talk to my Lady a little,
While I play with my Dog.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I am commanded
Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Heavens deliver me from this Impertinent!

div.stage: Per. and the Lady as in discourse, while Clay is stalking up and down whistling, &c.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Oye, oye, let him alone for Compliments.
I stoo-her, mouth: he'll give you your belly full
Of Compliments, and Courtship, and what not?
I'll play him 'gainst any in Town or Country
At either of those Weapons for a great.
Oye, stick closs to her man, oye, oye, look on.
I know 'tis all for me he speaks to you:
For why? he is my mouth, are you not, mouth?
How do you like him, Lady?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: 'Tis all the better for me still, I cry.
I pray sit down. This London, Lady mine,
Is a chargeable place. Nay, look on me;
sp.stage: Lady minds not Clay, looks on Per.
sp.l: He is only to speak, not to look on.
What do you think 't has cost me, do you see,
Since I'm in Town, on me, on Clunch, and Tray?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What is't you said?

div.stage: Clay pulls her, to make her hear.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Well, Lady, for this bout
I will not pose you in't; but in a lump
'T has cost me just seven Nobles, d'you see.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What person, Sir, is this you have brought with you?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: It is my Mouth; I told you so before,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: A Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Gentleman, d'you see, that will speak you—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And are you sure he is a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Our Neighbour Airy told me so, I'm sure;
And this I know, she would not lye for th'matter.
I tell you once more, he's a Gentleman
Every inch on him: do but try him else;
He'll give you, do you see, your belly full.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: This works for me beyond imagination.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Nay, but pray hear me out: I brought him here,
That in case you lov'd Compliments, d'you see,
A should sit your turn, Lady, t'a Cow's thumb,
As one should say: for, for my part,
I naturally hate these Compliments.
Look on him, Lady, pray.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: A good presence.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Effecks I'm woundy dry: Clunch fetch two Pots
To make my Lady drink.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, use my Cellar:
It is the fittest place for such a beast.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Efecks a match, a match; come hither Tray.
Nay, well all go: I'll lead in Tray, d'you see?
And you, Clunch hand my Lady: As for Mouth,
He is only to talk.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Hands off.

div.stage: Clunch offers to take the Lady by the hand, she flies off. Exeunt Clay and Clunch.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Chuse chub.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Now I begin t'abhor that foolishness
Which possest me so late. I am justly punished
For my covetousness; plainly foresee
I shall become a laughing-stock to all.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Madam, if that—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, answer me first:
Are you a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I am so, Lady.
But Madam, give me leave to let you know
My miseries, the crossness of my Stars,
Those fatal Influences did preside
At th'hour of my Birth—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What, Sir, can make you
So unhappy a man, as you endeavour
To represent your self?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis this:
That being extracted of a Gentile stock
Honourably deriv'd, have been imbu'd
With a proportion'd breeding to my Birth,
I should want that great Idol of the world,
A futable Estate to all those things
I have but newly mention'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: A comely man;
Me thinks I am concern'd at his relation:
Pray, Sir, how long have you known Mr. Clay?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Only since morning, Madam, have I seen
This man possest with that great lump of treasure
Which renders him ridiculous to the world;
While the hundred part of that vast Estate
Might intitle some worthy gentleman
To your consideration.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Would I were certain
This person were of a Gentile extraction.
When're I cast my Eye upon his preson,
Me thinks I do him wrong to question it.
I feel somewhat within me takes his part,
That will not let me rest, but whisperes still
Unto my heart, This man's to be prefer'd
With his bare virtue, before that other thing
With all its wealth. Come, Sir, we'll in an see
What is become of Mr. Timothy Clay
And his followers.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Madam, I'll wait upon you.

div.stage: (Per. takes the Lady by the hand, Exeunt.)

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: CHampagne, this is the night which is design'd
For my Amorous Theft: you must assist
With secrecie, be sure?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Secret, Jerny, no feere for dat:
Mee be all de secret, mee have de secret
To kill the Ratts, de Fleese, de Mooss, de Tick;
De secret to make de Money, to make de Charme,
To cash de prity Vensh; de secret de make de loose
De grate Belee, de botte secret, de Jerny—
De secret— to runn avay vit your monee and close.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Noting, noting, mee only repette all de mee secret.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Against the time, provide your self for action
With useful arms, such as you handle best.
'Tis like we may imploy them— do you see,
'Tis a dangerous attempt?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Oh! let mee come.
Begar, if dare be de bougre, de Rogue dat vill
Make de resistance, me voul come ca give
De him un grand posh— den vit come ca kill de him.
Presentement, ha—

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Hold, sure th'art mad?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Is begar, ven you speak de feet, mee be mad, de Kill de all.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Besides, you must provide you a disguise.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Disquise: ho! very goot, no fere for dat,
Mee voul disquise as mosh redicul as de you.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Come, let's hear how?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Mee voul go in de estable, take de little horse,
Mee voul kill de him, den mee voul take de his
Skinn et pote upon de mee, den mee voul keek, and
Beet et Cree whin hin: humrfl. is no excellant?
Disquise?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Yes, but I loose my horse by th' bargain, man.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Den mee do autrement, mee take de his skinn,
And no kill de him; den ven me don vitt de
Skin, mee put de it ope de horse again:
Is no dat good, no?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Still I should loose my horse.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Pox de horse: you get de Madmoisell? is no better.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: We'll think on't, man: This night's to prove
To me a night of Pleasures, and of Love.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.
div.stage: Young Airy solus, in Riding habit.
div.l: DIck Airy, th'art in London once again;
And now, what's to be done? I know not faith:
I'll examine my Pockets, see what's left
Of Lands, Chattels, and Goods, Money and all;
All I have in the world is in this place.
Let's see, what have we here? just seven Guinies;
I'll to the Ordinary, there I'll try
Whether these seven pieces I have left
Are good breeders or not; if not, why then
I shall but lose what would do me no good
To keep, except 'twere more: however, then
I shall be throughly clear'd of that small stock
Which never did me good since the first hour
My Father left it me. How he came by't
I know not; let that pass: then will I try
What I can do of my own self to live:
What know I but Fortune would prove more kinde
Were this gone also?
Unwilling peradventure I should owe
My happiness to any thing but she.
I'll try her once; Fortune, an't be thy will
To have me loose this Gold, yet help me then,
Meerly out of stark kindeness and pure love.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: QUe dis honneur es un foolish de ting!
Et que un box de Ear cause mosh trouble!
Ho mosh un vaillant man, most have de business?
For un box de Ear mee most now kill de him
Dat give it de mee; it is que de forst time
He strick de mee, for all dat he most dee.
But mee is de opinion dat is very de simple
To go de feet vit simplement de shart,
Becaus der be veree grat many places
To kill de man, and so de send de him
To de Antipodes. Der is de Hart,
De Livre, de Kiddeneis, de Longs, de Gots,
De Artere, de Vains, de Nerfs, et d'Estomach;
Derfor, as un prudant et vaillant home,
Mee have prepared de arms cap espee.
Mee have de very good parade, contre de Tierce,
De Cart, de Coup four; et contre de Back-sword:
As par example, mee see mee enemy
Just befor de mee, mee draw, ha! ders for you.
Begar me stick de him just in de pansse:
Jerny, mee parre vell? a ha! do you go back?
Alon, ventre Jerny, der to you head:
Ha! if mee no go back, mee have de hol
Justement in de hart, you paye for dat!
Ha! very goot, par ma foy: mee kill de Eye!
Bon, Jerny, mee kill de odre: O! blind man?
You most, Jerny, have de dog et de bell.
Hellas! Monsieur Champagne, mee aske pardon:
No Jerny, no most dee: He! pardon— no pardon.

div.l: Begar Madamoiselle you come de very goot tim.
Autrement me have kill de Rogue.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: What? who? where? why?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Par ma foy is just go.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Mee voul go fesh de him,
And kill de him for your service.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: No, good Champagne—

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Maistre Champagne, Jerny.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Then good Mr. Champagne,
Let him live for my sake.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Vell, live den, car Madmoiselle
sp.stage: Looks out, as speaking to some body—
sp.l: Vill have de it so.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Well, have you got the name?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Begar, mee know de all mee voul tell de you,
But you love de mee very vell den,
And let mee do de little ting—

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Nothing, nothing begar, mee only say
You have de mee for your Osban, is no?

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: I promise here, Champagne, to Marry you.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Aye! Monsieur Champagne?

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: Monsieur Champagne, I mean.
At the same hour your Rogue-Master shall wed
That Mistriss he's about.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Toshe de hand:
Mee tell de you in secret—

div.stage: Enter Sir Cog. Phill. Nob. Dian. Siss.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I suppose, Sir, that you are now return'd
From th'assignation?
What did the Lady say?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, I will inform you punctually
Of all that past between us. The Lady come
At the appointed place, caused the Chair
She was in to be stopp'd, and thus began.
There is a Lady not far from this place,
Of Beauty, Youth, Birth, and Estate to boot,
Not inferiour to the rich Lady Lovewealth,
Has such Esteem, Affection, if not Passion,
Or rather Love for your personal worth,
As cannot be express'd in lesser terms
Than making you her Husband.
Sir, you must know,
This night she does intend in a disguise,
To Mascarade it at the Lady Lovewealth—
Where I'll be sure to accompany her.
Madam, here's all
That has past 'twixt the Lady and my self.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I finde I am not in the least suspected.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Well Lysse, what news now?

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: None, Sir, but good.
These were his words, as well as he could speak,
Or I them understand. Mee Mastre's Mistriss is a
Young Lady whose name is Mrs. Kitty Noble.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: How, Kitty Noble, say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.p: This night, at three, my Master de Rogue and I steel her away, and cheat mee Master the fool of his fine Miss by a Ladder of Ropes, out of a window next to the Garden-wall at the Boarding-school in our own street. He added, that this Master was to be disquis'd like a Woman, and he he knew not yet. This did he jabber in his Gibberish tone.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Come, come, fear nothing, Sir, all will do well;
This works as I could wish: your assignation
At the Lady Lovewealth once at an end,
If you do not succeed, we'll watch th' old Knight,
And seize upon that most villanous Rogue
That sets him on meerly for his own ends,
As we may clearly see beyond dispute
By Lysse's late intelligence: we know the hour—
And there's no fear but to compass our ends.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, if that—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Sir, I hope you'll excuse
My absence this night from the Lady Love wealths?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: And do you leave me, Madam?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: She is not well.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I shall wish you good sport, and good success.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Come Sister, you'll along?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Yes, she shall go,
And Lysse too.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Come, come, let's loose no time.
Madam, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Servant, Lady.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Phill. and Siss.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Hast thou got all things ready?

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: Madam, I have.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Cupid prosper and crown this last nights work!

sp.speaker: Siss,
sp.l: watch their goings forth, and in what dress
Sir Coggin is accoutred; and when th'are gone,
Advertise me, that we may after them
With diligence. Surely it is impossible
I should be known in a Torch-bearer's habit,
With such a Mask as will hide all my face?
Thou being the Lady too?

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: I must confess,
That this change put upon them, will help much
To your concealment.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: It will: be gone; make haste.

div.l: Who's this that knocks? I would not be seen now:
I'll hide the light, and then let them in.
Who's there?

sp.speaker: Brave.
sp.l: A Friend.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: 'Tis more than I know yet.

sp.speaker: Brave.
sp.l: I can't help that. Sir Coggin? is it you?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: Brave.
sp.l: I'm glad I've met you, Sir, though in the dark:
I have but some few words—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Your business, pray?

sp.speaker: Brave.
sp.l: My business is but short: Mr. Crosby,
From whom I came, has desired me to say
You had not, Sir, that Title in Phill. Airy,
Or any of that worthy Ladies Virtues,
As he himself has, and does hold by right;
And on the same accompt, desires to see you
In the Piazza with your sword in hand,
At six this morning.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I'll wait upon him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Brave.
sp.l: It will be requisite you take a friend;
Your Rival honours me.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: That shall be done.

sp.speaker: Brave.
sp.l: I am your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Sir, I am yours.

div.l: Now am I challeng'd: O! here comes my Second.

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: I come to tell you that the coast is clear.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Come, let us to the Coach, and as we go
I'll tell thee the best Jest that ever was.

div.head: SCENE III. Lovewealth's house.
div.l: Lady Lovewealth, Per. Clay, Clunch, Tray, Prew.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: A Vadds, now, do you see, my head does ake
Like any wild-fire? hark you, my Lady?
Now, do you keep of all these sorts of Liquors
In your own Cellar, all the year about?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yes, yes, why not?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Why then y'are woundy rich.
What's your name, Prew?

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: My name is Prudence, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I prithy look my head.

div.stage: Sets himself on a Chair, his legs over the Ladies lap, and his dog in his. Lady rises in anger, discourses with Per.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No flesh and bloud
Can bear this insolence.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: 'Tis very cold;
Fecks we'l to Blind-man's-bluff: 'twill heat us all.
Clunch shall be hid.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Not I; I know your tricks.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I am waggish sometime, Lady, d'you see,
And he is wary of me: come, I'll hide.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: I'll blinde you then.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: No, my Lady shall do't.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: No, no, d'you mark me, I'll have no such cheating.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: So, o-brave Clunch, that calls my Lady cheat!
Th'art so mistrustful— come along simpleton:
Hold, hold, Clunch, not so hard.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Is it well now?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Oye, oye, d'you see, I'll have no goings out.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: No, no, come on.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Heavens! what will this be?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A cure I hope to your brains and my fortune.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Have at you Clunch; you do not clap your hands.
I warrant you this was Clunch. I taught him that.
I'll fit him for't.

div.stage: Clunch lays himself down, Clay falls over him.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Ods wowks, what have we here?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I'll tell you what, if I do catch you, Clunch.
Oh! have I caught you now, Clunch? Devil, Oh!

div.stage: Catches the Wheel barrow, runs away crying.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What's this insolencie for?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: But Mascarades.
How his anger becomes him? all he doth
Has so much grace—

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I would I were a whom.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I would to Heaven thou had'st never been here.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Had I know, Lady, that your house was haunted,
I'd ne're a come so far to marry you.
What do I know, d'you see, but when we two
Were in one bed minding of somewhat else,
We should have these Hobgobblings come to us,
And so mar all our sport? Pray now how long
Has your house been haunted? what say you Mouth?
Won't they hurt Tray? nor Clunch? nor you? nor me?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Observe, they dance.

div.stage: After the Dance exeunt all the Maskers, but the Wheel-bar.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Th'are merry Devils fecks.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Hy-day; more Devils yet?

div.stage: Enter Sir Amorous and Champagne in a Spanish Garb.
Champ. dances a Saraband, or Antique.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Whow! Hell's broke loose.

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: Sir, if you dare put confidence in me,
Here I protest that in every respect
She is to Madam Phill. Airy equal,
If not to be prefer'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Well, Madam, since
I must not hope to see the Lady's face
Before I've given my hand, and must confess
You have been just in all y'have hitherto
Declar'd to me; my life and fortunes both,
I put into your hands, to dispose of
As you shall best think fit.

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: Then give me leave
To speak you at this time a happy man:
Some minutes, Sir, will make you say the same.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, I am all faith.

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: Give me your hand,
To dispose with your heart, as I think fit.

div.stage: She gives it to Phill. he starts at the habit.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: What, wedded to a boy? Madam, what's this?
Sure I am not so tame as you imagin,
To have this put upon me thus?

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: Now, Madam,
It is time to discover.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: How, Madam, say you?

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: But shew your face, then you clear all suspicion
In this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Will this, Sir, serve the turn?.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Heavens!
But once more let me gaze; my happiness
Is so wonderful great, I can't believe it.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: What think you now?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: What think I Madam?
I cannot think, nor speak, nor see, nor hear.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Peace, not a word: hold up the humour still,
That we may not disturb my Brother in his Amour.
Your Sister and I, Sir, will borrow your Coach
While you two catch the Old Knight in's own trap:
Then we'll expect you home. Run in no danger.
Remember y'are mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Be pleased, Madam,
I'th' interim, to partake of our Banquet?

div.stage: They open the Wheel-barrow, take out the Sugar-plums that lie at top, throw them about, then present the sweet-meats to the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: 'Tis likely, Sir, you know not your own minde?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: I'll give it you under what Oath you please.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: That, Sir, perhaps is too serious a thing
For any thing you mean. And then, besides,
Do but consider our young acquaintance, Sir,
Which is not a month old.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: An Age in Love!
Who with industrious wings should leave behinde
The formal hours, nor is our meeting, Madam,
To be assign'd to any portion of them,
Since it was meant as soon as we took breath;
And is but reconcil'd to accidents
That make it up.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: A new Philosophy?
Well, Sir, go on.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: A mumble, Clunch?
Hye Tray, there; mumble boys.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: And should we add to it (I mean that time)
A cheap account of years, they cannot give
The more authority to my Vows, nor wrong
The honourable Favours you may showre
Upon your Servant. These things well consider'd,
You must conclude, Madam, tis with a form,
An idle custom, you would now comply
Against my happiness.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Well, Sir, in short,
Since by my Brother I'm inform'd you are
A person much deserving, and that besides
I'm wholly guided by him in this choice,
You promising so fair, henceforth you'll have
More than a Mistriss in title of me;
And for the future, 'tis like I'it command:
Think how you can obey.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Obsequiously;
Nothing within the circle of my power
To be exempted, Madam.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: On these conditions,
I may be bold, Sir, to give you my hand.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: And I to seal them, Madam,
On the white authors of my happiness.

div.stage: (Kisses her hand. Sir Cog. presents the Heart to Phill. other parts to the other Ladies.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Sure, Sir, that's done already, is it not?
Or I have lost by th' bargain.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: 'Tis so, Madam;
And this is meerly Emblematical.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Now for some Hyppochras!

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: White or red, Madam?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Either, Sir, both.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: How do you like your Liquors?

div.stage: Wrest an arm, draw Claret, draw white as from the Bladder.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: They are good.
I'll try your skill once more; some Jelly now:
What are his brains turn'd to that substance too?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: They are the kindest Devils that e're I saw;
