Are they not, Clunch?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: my Brother plies it close;
I hope he will carry the Widow.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Whoe're you are accept my hearty thanks
For your most pleasant and seasonable pastimes.
No longer between interest and love
Shall my heart wavering be, but chuse
The latter for his god, and with disdain
Renouncing Pluto, Cupid's slave remain.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I. Covent-garden.
div.stage: Young Airy▪ solus in the dark.

sp.speaker: Y. Airy.
sp.l: WHy this is well: when things are at the worst,
They commonly do mend; so may my fortune.
But first let me be sure there's none o'th'dregs
Of the late stock behinde, lest that a little
Of the old leaven should ferment that Mass
Which is to come; send it after the rest
To th' Devil head-long: what have I got here?
sp.stage: Airy searches his Pockets, finds a Guiny, weighs it in's hand.
sp.l: Another Devil in a golden dress?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: No, Sir, Heavens defend, I am the Parson
You have appointed to marry you this night.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.l: What's this you say?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: That five hundred a year,
And a young handsome Wife i'th' bargain, Sir,
Should make you diligent, and loose no time.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.l: Hold Fortune; not so fast, lest I should surfeit.
How, fawning of a sudden? Here, take this.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I thank you, Sir; there needs not so much haste;
I could a stayed till the business were done.
Sir, I'll be gone, and wait at the Church-porch,
Where first you did appoint me for to be:
There I'll expect you both to tye the Knot.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.l: Hist! hist!— the Devil I gave him but now
sp.stage: Kitty lets fall the Lander of ropes on him, 〈…〉.
sp.l: Has carried him away, and with him all
The budding hopes I had— How now? what's this?
A Rope? 'tis so: ready fastned for use?
I thank thee Fortune however for this,
But beg your pardon if I slight your favour.
A Ladder of Ropes? there's something in the winde,
Some Lover's assignation, or some thieves;
It may be either. Should it be the last,
It were but charity to warn the house.
If't proves the first, as probably it may,
As far as I can guess, by th' late discourse
I had with him my Devil took away;
Why may not I expect from a Ropes end,
What was deni'd me by all other means,
An end of all my miseries at once,
As many finde? I'll up and try th'Event,
Whatsoever it be.

div.stage: Enter▪ Sir Am. Shift, Champ. Per.
After, Enter Nob. Cog. and Slye.
They grope in the dark for the Ladder.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: We must grope for this Ladder in the dark.

div.stage: These 3 lines are spoken while Airy gets up the Ladder.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Go you one way, and I'll another take.
And he that findes the Ladder first, gets up.

div.stage: Gets up the Ladder into the window, feels out Kitty, takes her by the hand; she seems surprized.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: I'm glad y'are come;
I thought you very long: is the Minister
At the Church-porch?

sp.speaker: Airy,
sp.l: Peace, peace.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: Come, let me lead,
I know the way o'th' house better than you.
Once more remember what a wise you get,
Young, Rich, and, though I say't, handsome to boot:
I hope, Sir, you'll deserve this happiness,
sp.stage: He answers not, but Kisses her hand.
sp.l: By your tender love to me.

div.stage: Sir Amorous findes first the Ladder, get up; Noble finds it next, stands aside of it holding it in his hand: Shift finds it next, goes to get up; Noble seizes on him, gives him to Sir Cog. and Slye 〈…〉 Sir Amorous stumbles in the dark, raises the 〈◊〉 a noise within, an out-cry of Thieves.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Jerny, mee save mee Modres shild; adieu.

div.stage: Thinking to run away, runs against a wall, falls backwards.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Madam, we are undone if you come not.
I beg it on my knees, make haste away,
Or say you will not go: what, not a word?

div.stage: Ranges about within: Dispatch to Madam Kitty's Chamber there.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Why, Madam, Madam? Oh! Heavens, she's gone;
And I'm so frighted, that I cannot move.
They come, and I'm undone—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Break down the door, it must be there.
Sieze on her there: what's this? a man apparell'd
In a womans dress? a pure Rogue this!

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.l: But where is Madam Kitty all this while?

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: Not to be found.

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.l: What a confusion's here?
Come along, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Thieves in disguise of Watchmen with a Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: Stand: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Here, here, seize on these Thieves, and hold them fast.
I took them in the act, robbing the School-house.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Impudent Rogue!

div.stage: (As Nob. and Sir Cog. offer to resist, they fall on um and disarm them.
Enter Women, with spits; forks, &c. bringing Sir Am.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: Come, come, bring forth the Thief:
Which is the Watch?

sp.speaker: Thieves.
sp.l: Here, here; What, more Rogues yet?

sp.speaker: Watchman.
sp.l: Stand: Who goes there?
Call the Constable ho.

div.stage: The true Watch whisper busily together.

sp.speaker: Thieves.
sp.l: We are the Watch.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Come, away with them there, to th' Justice, Sirs.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: To Justice Frost we'll go.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Yes, there I'll go.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: No, Sirs, you shall go to some other Justice.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: To Justice Frost.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: Yes, yes, they shall go there.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: But I say no.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: What Ward are you of, friends?

sp.speaker: Thieves.
sp.l: Of Covent-garden Watch.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Seize on the Rogues,
W'are Covent-garden Watch: how, counterfeits?
We'll teach you t'faleyfie the King's Majesty
I'th' person of his constable and Watchmen.
Along, along, to Sir Amorous Frost with them.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: This works well now.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: As well as heart could wish.

div.head: SCENE II. Lady Lovewealth's house.
div.stage: Enter Lady Lovewealth, Per. leading her. Clay, Clunch, and Tray.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: WEll, well, since it is so, I'll e'ne march off;
So Lady fare you well: come Tray, come Clunch,
Come mouth, we'll home.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, I must beg your pardon,
If I make bold to detain this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: To teach you Compliments.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: For that same purpose,
And frequently to practice Courtship with him,
That I may be expert.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Practice, expert.
She begins well already— e'ne stay with her.
For as well, in our Town, wee have no need
Of Complimenters, nor of Courtiers neither.
There will I in all haste, so fare you well.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: There will I in all haste, so fare you well.
Come, Tray, bid them farewel.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I must return you, Sir, thanks for those pains
Which you have taken to render me sensible
Of my late folly, my covetous minde:
Therefore in gratitude to your civilities,
I give you this assurance to be yours.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And I, Madam, with a most servent Love,
And most obsequious Services? will pay
My offerings to this Altar every day.

div.head: SCENE III. Sir Am. his house.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: BRing in the Prisoners there, make room before.

div.stage: Enter Champ. laughs at his Master. Exit.
div.l: Come, where's his worship? let him know w'are here.
div.stage: Enter Crosby. Noble steals off; Crosby would retire, the Watchmen detain him.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: No, no, we know your tricks.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Gentlemen, look all to your Prisoners there.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: Let's count them over.

div.stage: They count, and reckon Crosby among them.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.l: Th'are right, th' are right.

sp.speaker: Crosb.
sp.l: Gentlemen, you mistake, I'm none o'th number;
Meerly Curiosity did bring me here.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: I think he came in since.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Then let him go.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Vish is de Constable?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Here, here, I am.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Mee Mr. bidd mee aske de you for de grate Teef
In de humans clos, he vill anser for de him.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Here, here a is; I warrant an old Thief:

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: By your leave, friends, you know me, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: My honest Landlord?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: I'm glad to see you well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: This Gentlewoman, Mrs. of the School,
Says, that through a mistake was all this stir:
She finds nothing amiss in all her house,
And therefore is come hither to treat
For the liberty of these Gentlemen:
It is not so?

sp.speaker: Crost.
sp.l: 'Tis as the Gentleman says.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Mr. Constable, a word with you in private.

div.stage: Brings him aside, whispers to him, gives him money.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: The Justice is very long.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.l: He was asleep;
'Tis like they could not wake him o'th' sudden.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Come, Gentlemen, let's go; I'm certifi'd.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.l: I hope they'll give us something though to drink?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: There, honest friends; good night.
sp.stage: Exeunt all but Nob. Sir Cog. Crost. and Slye.
sp.l: Good Mrs. Crostitch, where found you my Sister?

sp.speaker: Crost.
sp.l: Passing by our house, as from that street
That leads to Covent-garden, a Gentleman
Leading her by the hand, by chance a glimpse
Of a neighboring light discover'd her to me.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: What did she say?

sp.speaker: Crost.
sp.l: Why, Sir, that she was married
To that Gentleman; which he own'd to be true.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: She is undone for ever! quite undone!
Where is she now?

sp.speaker: Crost.
sp.l: Sir, she is at my house,
Where she said she would stay till you came to her.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Go and be with her, pray, until I come.
This business manag'd well, Sir, may be worth
A thousand pounds a year.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: That I must do.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: I'll to my Sister go, examine her;
While you'll do well to go to the old man
And try what you can do, while he is yet
In's pannick fears.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Be sure I'll do my best.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: I'll take my Sister with me to your house.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: My house is yours, you know; Now must I go
To the old Knight with a most griveous story,
No less than Burglary and rape i'th' Gase,
And those with aggravations—

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Nephew, undone!
Undone for ever in my Reputation.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: I hope not so, dear Sir, though had enough.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: What's become of the rest? Oh! fatal hour!

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Sir, by my means convey'd out of the way,
Not far from hence.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Now Child, what's to be done?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Sir, for the present I have stopp'd all proceedings,
Though 'twill break out again.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Too soon, I fear.
Well Nephew, though 'tis late, I see my fault,
And most deservedly am punish'd for't:
I put my self, and Reputation both,
Into your hands; preserve them both as yours.
I shall requite you, and in consideration
O'th' wrong I would of late have done you, Nephew,
I will allow you, during my whole life,
A thousand pounds a year; and at my death,
The whole reversion of all my Estate.
Let's in, and there I'll confirm the Deed to you
Before sufficient witnesses, till I can
Get the Writings drawn up.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Honoured Sir,
My life and honour shall for evermore
Stand between you and any sort of danger.
That no time may be lost, I'll instantly
To th'company, and take upon my self
The whole adventure. I hope I shall finde friends
To get me off for some small sum of money.
It will be said of me, it was my youth.
Thus, Sir, your Reputation will be safe,
Your Person out of danger, and—

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: I instantly
Will send to have the Writings drawn up,
With all the haste that may be.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Sir, good night.

div.head: SCENE IV. Sir Cog. house.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: PRethy, dear heart, content thy self a while;
Th' appointed hour was between five and six,
And 't has but just struck five.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.l: My dearest friend,
Pardon my Jealousies—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Be chearful then;
I'll lay my life 'twill do.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.l: Should your plot fail,
I were undone past all hopes of repair.
Is the Parson come yet?

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: Yes, long ago;
Waits in the Chamber next my Ladies closet,
Has but cold comfort on't.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: He's in the dark.

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: H'as neither fire, nor light,
And is lock'd up.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Come Siss, along with me to the Piazza.

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: Madam, I cannot fight.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: No matter, Wench,
I'm stout enough for both.

sp.speaker: Siss.
sp.l: Without a sword?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I'll leave you, Madam; you must have no light:
Let me alone to put the Change upon him.
Here comes some company, retire quick.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Well, Madam Sister, have you done your do?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Faith, dear Sister, not yet; but one plot more,
And then no more: Where's your Brother, Madam,
And Mr. Noble?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Not yet return'd, you see;
But sure they'll not be long.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Well, I must go,
I shall not stay 'bove half an hour, at most.
I hope at my return to finde all here.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Madam, how dare you venture all alone
At this unseasonable hour?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I fear no Colours!

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: This new Sister of mine is a mad thing.
What strange things she has acted here of late!
And still with good success.

sp.speaker: Lysse.
sp.l: She has her ends.
Siss has told me, her Mrs. made no question
But that she would procure her self a Husband,
And her Brother a wife, in two days space;
And had her other Brother been in Town,
'Twould have gone hard but she'd a fitted him
With a wife also.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: She has done pritty well,
Having made sure for her self of my Brother,
Has put hers also in so fair a way
To th'Lady Lovewealth, it is ten to one
But he will carry her: but here he is,
And by his chearful looks I hope all's well.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: The night being far spent, and knowing, Madam,
There was such work in hand as would detain you
From your accustom'd rest, we have made bold,
This fair Lady and I, to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Madam, I had no sooner given this Gentleman
A power over me, but he has made use of it
In commanding me hither.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: By your advice.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: I am o'rejoy'd, Sir, to see your success,
And wish your Ladyship all happyness
In this your choice.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: As I do you in yours.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: I humbly thank your Ladyship, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Nay, for my part, I'm fully perswaded
That all the Stars are in a close conjunction
This very night: but, Madam, where's the rest?
My Sister, Madam—

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Gone about some new plot.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Madam, here comes your Brother and his Mate.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Brother, speak, hast thou sped?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I'll answer for him.
Madam, he may thank your politick head
For having me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And my well acting in it.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I hope by this I've made an other match
Since I went hence.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: As how? pray let us hear.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Mr. Crosby being highly incensed
Against you, Sir, whom he knew was his Rival,
Was pleas'd this night to send a Challenge to you.
I in your absence, by the help of the dark,
Receiv'd that Message, which he thought he had given
To your own self. I was but just return'd
From the Rendezvous, where finding the mistake
His Second had made, with some fair words,
And a promise of Marriage, I've brought him home.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: How! a promise of Marriage, do you say?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Yes, yes, which by this time I have made good
I hope, and yet no prejudice to you,
As you shall hear. The abused Lady Phanny
Through his wildness, as you know I had above,
And a Parson in readiness in the dark,
Under pretence of not being discovered,
He gave consent it should be without light:
There having brought Mr. Crosby, just now
l've slipt my hand from his, and in exchange
Have given him the Lady Phanny's hand:
I left them in this posture, the Minister
Doing his office readily without book.
So giving them the slip, I am come hither.
By this, I hope th'are fast.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: I wish it so.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why here is plot enough to make a Play!

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Oh! here they come, and by their countenance
I hope all's well.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Where's my Trappanner, ho!

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I hope, Sir, you have pardon'd my deceit.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: I thank your goodness for it, and do confess
You are that happy Star has guided me
To this shun'd haven which will prove my Bliss,
Since I have paid that debt which through my Vows
I had contracted here. Your pardon, Sir,
For those thoughts I once harbour'd against you
My Rival then, but now I hope my friend,
What say you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: That here you may command
Your Lady too.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: How now? who have we here?
My Brother sure, or I am in a dream?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Our Brother, Madam.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.l: 'Tis impossible, sure.

sp.speaker: Y. Airy.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis even so: I am a married man,
And this my Lady, Brother.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: Thank your fortune!

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Sister, and so may you, that he is yours.
For your sake, Sir, I'll forget her late folly,
And thank the Heavens for designing her yours
At the same time she sought her own destruction.

sp.speaker: Y. Airy.
sp.l: You are all goodness, Sir, to pardon thus
My late presumption.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: All shall be now forgot:
This is a night of Jubilee; from hence
We must banish all sorrow.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Pray let me come,
I'm Mrs. of the house, am I not, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: And of me too.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I thought so much at least;
Therefore, dear Brother, I must bid you welcome,
And to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Y. Airy.
sp.l: Dear Sister, humble thanks.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: Madam, for your sake, I'll praise him the more.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: My very good friends all, I am come here
To make my recantation, own my fault,
And willingly set a fine on my head
For my late folly: I therefore in presence
Of all are here, declare this Gentleman, my Nephew,
Sole Heir to my Estate, after my death:
During my life, allow him every year
One thousand pound. To this pray witness all,
Till I have made it good in lawful form
Under my Hand and Seal.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog. and Phill.
sp.l: We thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: All these joynings of hands, and no dance to't?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Come, come, I'm for a dance, in which you'll see,
Though distinct Couples, we can all agree.

div.stage: After which, Enter Slye haling of Champagne.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: O! have I caught you, Sir? Now sirrah, either fight
With me presently, or prepare to die.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ha! ha! ha! Begar me tink de fellow is made;
Vat pox do you no see dat de la Commedy is finish? look de
Your part, you will finde no sush ting: go, go, and let de mee
To de la Compagnie.

div.stage: Champ. addresses to the Audience, the Epilogue.
div.p:
Gentliman, do in de la Comedye mee most no fitt, but me most swear, mee naturellement love de fit: et Jerny mee voul no swear;
derefor par consequent mee come to tell de you, dat mee be de Poet Champion. If dere be man, homan, or little shild dat vill no clape de hand, and swear Jerny de Comedye is very good, begar, mee swear is no de understand de vit, nor de raison, et mee presentement turne de la Comedye in de la Tragedy. Alon Jerny—
div.stage: Draws and flourishes during the Clap.
After the Clap, goes on thus.
div.p: So, very good; now because you be all de civility, mee promiss sur mon honneur, mee voul no kill de you, and mee give de you de permission to come here to morrow agin (for your argent Jerny) et so Mesieurs adieu; mee go tell de Poet de your courtoisie.
